content.description: Climb the steep right side of the big globe feature. Follow blocky holds trending up and left on 11+ climbing to a beta intensive crux above the 3rd bolt. Could be 13a?
content.location: Big overhanging globe feature on the backside of Adit Rock

content.description:
Climb the wide crack/chimney that splits the face from top to bottom.   

  Climbing the offwidth top section can be avoided by climbing on face hold to the right of the crack.
content.protection: Standard rack to 5 inches.  You need big gear to protect the top, which is also probably the crux of the route.
content.location: Obvious crack to the right of the giant leaning flake

content.description: Climb to the top of the pillar on solid rock. Crux is pulling the overhang to the anchors.
content.location: Outside face of the leaning rock that forms the tunnel. Left of Instant Replay crack.

content.description: As the name suggests, this route is short but what it lacks in height it more than makes up for in easy fun and sometimes awkward moves along this corner crack climb. The crux would depend on your style.
content.protection: Pro to 3". Anchors on your right at the roof.
content.location: look for the obvious crack on the left side of the big roof. it looks more intimidating than it actually is.

content.description: Shockingly fun for a 5.4 on Staender Ridge.  Great rock, good movement.  If you were interested in a couple of other routes near Adit Rock, and were looking for something different, this could be a great excuse for a diversion from the typical day at Smith.  Use this route and a couple others as a good first day of the season, or a nice place to go when you're injured, and still want to climb.
content.location: Find Adit Rock - the closest large formation to the river on Staender Ridge.  Tread as lightly as possible on the trail up, erosion could become an issue here.     You'll know the route because it's riddled with attractive pockets, it faces the river, its low angle, and it has fresh bolts on it.  It's around to the right when you look up at the rock from the river, near the great looking sharp arete and a funny little 5.7 slab.

climbs.name: Is This Love?
climbs.fa: Ryan Lawson, October 2000  B.R. Matt Canham, 2002.1

content.description: This route was given two stars in the guide book but I decided to bump it up on here. The gear is truly unique, and the climbing is truly awkward. the crux is everything This route used to be bolted along the outside of the bombay crack but has since been chopped. The only way to do it now is to either set up nice guy's and top rope the outside edge of the crack or go all out and lead it from inside the depths of this gaping crack. The lead is awesome. My only complaint was the length. so short.
content.protection: Pro to 4". I would say that a 4" or 5" piece would be nice. This is one of the few Routes I've ever climbed that took Hexes better than any other piece I own. The crack has a wierd shape that you can slide hexes along with you as you treverse the cave. Anchors are same as Nice Guy's. Rap.
content.location: look for the 20' bombay crack on the left side of adit rock. Not too hard to find.

content.description: The left of the 2 obvious crack systems on the South face of Adit Rock. Climb the crack through cruxy bulge to anchors hidden behind a block.
content.location: On the south face of Adit Rock.

content.description: Bouldery crux at beginning leads to fun slab climbing above.
content.location: Around the west side of adit rock.

climbs.name: Anti-Reflective
climbs.fa: May 1999 by Marco Fedrizzi & Greg Lyon

content.description: Upon arriving at Adit Rock you'll be directly under the steep arÃªte that is Anti-Reflective.  Hop on top of the pillar, clip the first bolt and get ready to do battle.  You'll get a few quick shakes on the route but never anything like a rest until clipping the anchor.  This is a good one to project as the falls are clean and the bolts are tightly spaced.  Speaking of bolts, several of them are surprisingly tiring to clip.
The lowest formation on Staender Ridge. Home to many of Ryan Lawsons newer sport routes as well as some old classics.
